Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story: My little brother and I were walking home from school, our backpacks bouncing with each step. I kept an eye on him, making sure he didn’t wander too close to the curb, just like Mom always asked. Suddenly, my phone buzzed. It was my best friend, Sam. I answered, and immediately heard the strain in his voice—he was upset, his words tumbling out about a fight with his partner. He needed me to listen, to be there for him, just like I always promised I would. But as I tried to focus on Sam’s voice, my brother darted ahead, chasing after a stray cat. My heart pounded. I wanted to give Sam my full attention, to be the friend he needed, but I couldn’t ignore my responsibility to keep my brother safe. I felt torn, guilt pressing in from both sides, unsure how to be both the sibling and the friend I was supposed to be.
